description: Elevator maintenance, troubleshooting, and service procedures

questions.question: What is the first step before performing any elevator maintenance?
options: Lock out/tag out the main disconnect and verify power is off
questions.explanation: Lockout/tagout (LOTO) is required before maintenance to prevent unexpected energization. Always verify power is off before starting work.

questions.question: What PPE is required for elevator maintenance?
options: Safety glasses, hard hat, safety shoes, and task-specific PPE
questions.explanation: Basic PPE includes safety glasses, hard hat, safety-toe shoes. Additional PPE depends on specific tasks - gloves for oil, hearing protection for machine rooms.

questions.question: How often should elevator machine room housekeeping be performed?
options: Monthly or as needed to maintain cleanliness
questions.explanation: Machine rooms should be kept clean and free of debris at all times. Housekeeping is part of regular maintenance visits.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a maintenance log?
options: Document all maintenance, repairs, and tests performed
questions.explanation: Maintenance logs document all work performed, findings, and test results. They're required by code and essential for tracking equipment history.

questions.question: What is preventive maintenance?
options: Scheduled maintenance to prevent failures before they occur
questions.explanation: Preventive maintenance (PM) includes scheduled inspections, cleaning, lubrication, and adjustments to prevent breakdowns.

questions.question: What should be checked during car top inspection?
options: Ropes, sheaves, car top equipment, door operators, safety switches
questions.explanation: Car top inspection includes checking ropes, roller guides, door operators, car top switches, governor rope, and all accessible equipment.

questions.question: What is oil analysis for hydraulic elevators?
options: Laboratory testing of oil for contamination, breakdown, and wear particles
questions.explanation: Oil analysis tests hydraulic oil for contamination, moisture, viscosity changes, and wear particles indicating component wear.

questions.question: How often should rope inspection be performed?
options: Monthly visual, with detailed inspection per schedule
questions.explanation: Hoisting ropes require monthly visual inspection for broken wires, wear, and corrosion, with more detailed inspections per maintenance schedule.

questions.question: What is governor rope inspection?
options: Inspecting the rope connecting the car safety to the governor
questions.explanation: Governor rope connects the car to the governor. It must be inspected for wear, broken wires, and proper tension.

questions.question: What pit inspection items are required?
options: Buffers, switches, sump pump, lighting, ladder, and cleanliness
questions.explanation: Pit inspection includes buffers, safety switches, sump pump (if equipped), lighting, ladder condition, and general cleanliness/water intrusion.

questions.question: What is door operator maintenance?
options: Inspection, lubrication, and adjustment of door operating mechanisms
questions.explanation: Door operator maintenance includes checking belts/chains, lubricating moving parts, adjusting speeds, checking door reopening devices.

questions.question: What is guide rail lubrication for?
options: Reducing friction for roller guides or providing safety contact for sliding guides
questions.explanation: Guide rails may need lubrication for sliding guide shoes. Roller guides generally don't require rail lubrication. Oilers maintain proper contact.

questions.question: What is rope equalization?
options: Making all ropes the same color
Adjusting rope tension so all ropes carry equal load
questions.explanation: Rope equalization adjusts individual rope tensions at the hitch so all ropes share the load equally, preventing premature wear.

questions.question: What causes premature rope wear?
options: Unequal tension, sheave wear, poor alignment, lack of lubrication
questions.explanation: Rope wear is accelerated by unequal tension, worn sheave grooves, misalignment, inadequate lubrication, and environmental factors.

questions.question: How is sheave groove wear measured?
options: Using a groove gauge to measure depth and shape
questions.explanation: Sheave groove gauges measure groove depth and profile. Worn grooves accelerate rope wear and must be re-grooved or sheave replaced.

questions.question: What is the procedure when elevator is out of service?
options: Place out of service sign, secure car, notify building management
questions.explanation: Out of service procedures include signage, securing the car at a floor with doors closed, notifying management, and logging the status.

questions.question: What brake maintenance is required for traction elevators?
options: Regular adjustment, lining inspection, and testing
questions.explanation: Brakes require regular inspection of linings, adjustment for wear, testing of holding capability, and checking release clearance.

questions.question: What is controller maintenance?
options: Cleaning, checking connections, testing circuits, updating software
questions.explanation: Controller maintenance includes cleaning, tightening connections, checking contactors, testing safety circuits, and software updates.

questions.question: How is door interlock operation verified?
options: Testing that car cannot run unless door is closed and locked
questions.explanation: Door interlock testing verifies the car cannot move unless hoistway doors are fully closed and electrically locked. Each door must be tested.

questions.question: What is leveling adjustment?
options: Adjusting control parameters so car stops at floor level
questions.explanation: Leveling adjustment ensures the car stops within the code-required tolerance of the landing sill (typically +/- 3/4 inch or better).

questions.question: What causes elevator callbacks (shutdowns)?
options: Safety device trips, component failures, or system faults
questions.explanation: Callbacks occur when safety devices detect problems (door faults, leveling errors, safety chain opens) or components fail.

questions.question: What troubleshooting tool displays fault codes?
options: Controller diagnostic display or diagnostic tool
questions.explanation: Modern controllers have built-in diagnostics that display fault codes. Portable diagnostic tools can also connect to retrieve fault history.

questions.question: What is rope retirement criteria?
options: Broken wire count, diameter reduction, and other damage criteria
questions.explanation: Ropes are retired when broken wires exceed limits, diameter reduces beyond tolerance, or other damage (corrosion, distortion) is found.

questions.question: How is hydraulic jack packing inspected?
options: Checking for external oil leaks around the plunger
questions.explanation: Packing condition is assessed by checking for oil leaks around the plunger where it exits the cylinder. Leakage indicates packing wear.

questions.question: What is the Category 1 periodic test?
options: Annual test of car and counterweight safeties without tripping
questions.explanation: Category 1 tests verify safety devices (governors, safeties) operate without actually engaging the safeties. Required annually.

questions.question: What is the Category 5 periodic test?
options: Full-load safety test with safeties engaged on the rails
questions.explanation: Category 5 is a full-load safety test where safeties actually engage on the rails. Required every 5 years for traction elevators.

questions.question: How are firefighter's service features tested?
options: Simulating fire alarm and testing Phase I recall and Phase II operation
questions.explanation: Phase I (recall) and Phase II (manual operation) must be tested regularly by activating the fire alarm simulation and verifying proper operation.

questions.question: What is bearing inspection on traction machines?
options: Checking for noise, vibration, temperature, and lubrication condition
questions.explanation: Bearing condition is assessed by checking for unusual noise, excessive vibration, elevated temperature, and proper lubrication.

questions.question: What is VFD maintenance?
options: Filter cleaning, connection checking, parameter verification, cooling check
questions.explanation: VFD maintenance includes cleaning filters, checking connections, verifying parameters, checking cooling fans, and inspecting capacitors.

questions.question: What is the purpose of emergency power testing?
options: Verifying elevator operation on emergency power
questions.explanation: Emergency power tests verify elevators designated for emergency operation actually function properly when running on generator power.

questions.question: What is the traveling cable inspection?
options: Inspecting the flexible cable from car to hoistway for wear and damage
questions.explanation: Traveling cables carry power and signals to the car. Inspection checks for wear, damage, proper support, and adequate length.

questions.question: What are diagnostic codes used for?
questions.explanation: Diagnostic codes identify specific faults (door issues, safety circuits, leveling problems) to help technicians troubleshoot efficiently.

questions.question: What is condition-based maintenance?
options: Maintenance based on actual equipment condition from monitoring data
questions.explanation: Condition-based maintenance uses monitoring data (vibration, temperature, usage) to schedule maintenance when actually needed.

questions.question: What buffer inspection is required?
options: Checking oil level (oil buffers), spring condition, and proper mounting
questions.explanation: Oil buffers require oil level and condition checks. Spring buffers need spring condition inspection. Both need mounting verification.

questions.question: What is the seismic switch test procedure?
options: Testing that the switch responds to specified G-force and shuts down elevator
questions.explanation: Seismic switches are tested by inducing the trigger motion (or using test features) and verifying the elevator shuts down properly.

questions.question: What is recall testing for?
options: Verifying elevators return to designated floors on fire alarm or seismic event
questions.explanation: Recall testing verifies that elevators properly return to the designated floor when fire alarm or seismic devices activate.

questions.question: What is the overspeed governor test?
options: Testing that governor trips at correct speed and activates safety
questions.explanation: Governor tests verify the governor trips at the correct overspeed and that it properly actuates the car safety device.

questions.question: What is the emergency release test?
options: Verifying the ability to manually release brakes/operate elevator for rescue
questions.explanation: Emergency release tests verify that trained personnel can manually release brakes and move the car to rescue trapped passengers.

questions.question: What documentation is required after completing tests?
options: Test results, date, tester name, and any deficiencies in the maintenance log
questions.explanation: Test documentation must include date, test performed, results (pass/fail), tester identification, and corrective actions needed.

questions.question: What is modernization assessment?
options: Evaluating equipment for upgrade or replacement to improve performance/safety
questions.explanation: Modernization assessment evaluates whether controllers, machines, doors, or fixtures should be upgraded for improved performance, reliability, or code compliance.
